title: How to access research papers for free - Quora

response.answer_text: In addition to the websites listed in Joshua Engel's answer, I would suggest the following other options:  Papers based on research that has been funded by the NIH are required to be available in an open-access manner, and are listed in PubMed Central. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/ If the topic you're interested in is biological or health-based, start here. (The NIH also funds a lot of basic research, so you will often find papers you wouldn't expect to here as well).Many scientists self-archive, that is, they keep .pdf copies of their papers and/or their proofs on their lab websites. If you know what you're looking for, go to the lab website of the scientist involved, you should be able to get a copy of the paper there.Email the scientist involved. Most people I know are only too happy to send an interested person a .pdf copy of their paper, if so requested. Most papers have a corresponding author whose contact information is listed along with the abstract. Send them an email.If you live near a major research university, visit their library. They will have access to an incredible array of journals and papers, both physically and online through university specific databases. You should be able to print out what you need there.

Free - Reddit ScholarRequest the article on Reddit Scholar. Within about 20 minutes, a scholar responds with a link to download the PDF of your journal article.1. Go to Reddit Scholar2. Register if you're not already.3. Post the Title, Author, and a Link to the journal article Alpha-actinin-3 levels increase concomitantly with fast fibers in rat soleus muscleYuji OguraAlpha-actinin-3 levels increase concomitantly with fast fibers in rat soleus muscle 4. Wait for someone to post your paper. (Here's the one I requested) Then do whatever you like with it!In my experience it takes about 20 minutes for someone to respond with your journal article. Sometimes the wait is longer. $4 - Read it on DeepDyveRent the article from DeepDyve, to read in your browser.1. Go to DeepDyve2. Search for your article (here's mine)3. Rent it for $4. "Rental" means you can read it for 30 days. No prints or downloads. $20 for 5 rental credits.Rental isn't an option for all articles. For instance, I can't rent this ACTN3 journal paper.A big mark down for Deepdyve: DeepDyve is horrible at telling you if an article is available for free somewhere else. I rented a copy of this paper (ACTN3 genotype is associated with increases in muscle strength in response to resistance training in women) from DeepDyve. When I clicked on their "Buy from Publisher" link, the paper was free online from JAP. In another case, DeepDyve said an article was "Buy only", but was free to download on Nature's website. I looked at 20+ results for ACTN3, and 80+% of them marked as "Rentable" were free from the publisher.But I want to like DeepDyve. If DeepDyve was more reliable about tagging "Free" journal articles, it would be my first stop when doing research. If the article was free, read it; if it's rentable, rent it; otherwise consider buying it. No more hunting around across so many websites! Would love to update this post in a few months and find that DeepDyve is much better. $30 - From the PublisherThe final option is buying the article from the Publisher directly. Normally the first result of a Google search is a link to the NCBI Pubmed website, linking to the publisher's site. My ACTN3 article costs $41.95. Yikes! In my experience prices range from $30 up to $60, depending on the Publisher.

I know this is an old topic, but it is the kind of topic that deserves frequent updates. I, too, fall in the camp that all academic research should be publicly available, but especially anything greater than 5 years old. Since finishing my graduate degree I have lost access to scholarly articles and miss that. So, this post will present this answer with two sets of links. The first set will be free journals or free databases giving access to free journals. The second will be pages that list sources of free academic research (I have not verified these). Free Journals and databases Directory of Open Access Journals ScienceDirect National Institutes of Health (NIH) National Library of Medicine National Center for Biotechnology Information Westminster Theological Seminary: Free Scholarly Research Links EBSCO: Free Databases | EBSCO Google Scholar: https://scholar.google.com ResearchOMatic: Free essay, research paper, thesis & dissertation -Researchomatic Potentially free resources JURN: search millions of free academic articles, chapters and theses SCRIBENDI: 101 Free Online Journal and Research Databases for Academics | Scribendi International Institute of Social Studies: Free scholarly resources Sci-Hub: sci-hub.io Scholarly Open Access Journal: https://www.omicsonline.org/scholarly-open-access-journals.php Truman State University: Free Databases

Following are some good sources of Scholarly Papers Business Source Premier Shibboleth Authentication Request  Includes both scholarly journals and periodicals for practitioners. Locate full-text coverage to more than 2,800 journals in business, economics, political science and public administration.Web of Science Shibboleth Authentication Request  Search within a comprehensive interdisciplinary collection of journal article citations. Subjects generally covered are within Science and technology, arts and humanities, and social sciences . Use the citation web to find articles and journals with the most impact. Coverage runs from 1975 to the present. Help can be found on their website.Google Scholar Shibboleth Authentication Request  Use Google Scholar through the Libraries' web site. Find scholarly literature, including peer-reviewed papers, theses, books, preprints, abstracts and technical reports from different areas of research.Scopus Shibboleth Authentication Request  An abstract and citation database with a single search platform searching content from ScienceDirect, Scopus, SciTopics, and relevant Web content.EconLit Shibboleth Authentication Request  Contains bibliographic citations and selected abstracts to the professional and scholarly literature in the field of economics and allied disciplines, including journals, books, chapters in books, conference proceedings and dissertations.PsycINFO Shibboleth Authentication Request  Going back to 1806, this is the most comprehensive database for psychological research. With a little guidance from this tutorial, you'll be able to go from a general idea to a very precise set of results of scholarly materials.Wiley Online Library Shibboleth Authentication Request  Full text collection to 1,000 journals, major reference works, online books from John Wiley, a publisher of scientific and social science literature. Remote access available for University of Minnesota -- Twin Cities students, staff, and facultyElsevier ScienceDirect Shibboleth Authentication Request  Remote access available for University of Minnesota -- Twin Cities students, staff and faculty Coverage 1998-present for most titlesSpringerLink Shibboleth Authentication Request  Online journals, e-books, conference proceedings, and reference titles from Springer Publishing. Covers many disciplines with separate collections for architecture and design, behavioral Science, biomedical and life sciences, business and economics, chemistry and materials sciences, computer science and information technology, environmental sciences, engineering, humanities, social sciences. law, mathematics and statistics, medicine, operational research, physics and astronomy.Historical Business Research Business Periodicals Index Retrospective Shibboleth Authentication Request  Indexes seven decades of articles on important events, issues and trends in the history of business and industry (including the complete file of Industrial Arts Index (1913-1957), plus historical sources in the applied science and technology field for the 20th Century. Covers more than 2,000 periodicals that include more than 4.5 million articles. An excellent resource for tracking down important studies, exploring historical controversies, finding papers by innovators, researching the development of a particular technology, and more. Applied Science & Business Periodicals Retrospective Shibboleth Authentication Request  Indexes seven decades of articles on important events, issues and trends in the history of business and industry (including the complete file of Industrial Arts Index (1913-1957), plus historical sources in the applied science and technology field for the 20th Century. Covers more than 2,000 periodicals that include more than 4.5 million articles. An excellent resource for tracking down important studies, exploring historical controversies, finding papers by innovators, researching the development of a particular technology, and more.JSTOR Shibboleth Authentication Request  Find full text articles in academic journals or books on the arts, humanities, social sciences, and sciences. JSTOR provides articles from the date of each journal's initial publication to recent issues. In some cases the latest several years may not be available.

If you are not associated with a university--where you could use the university library online--then check out becoming a member of a local major public library.  Major public libraries--Los Angeles, New York, etc.--often have good research collections, including online access to subject databases and full-text journals, which you can use as a member of the library.  You would input your library card number to get access online.  Also, rules differ from campus to campus, but often you can pay for an annual membership in a local university library, and be able to get online access that way.  Finally, though you may hate the thought, if you go in physically to a university library, even without any membership, you can usually do online searching of databases and journals right in the physical library, and print off references and papers there at no or little cost. As for strictly online websites: disciplines often have some database or repository you can use, but it varies by field. If  you are a computer scientist, you can get online access to the full text of all the dozens of ACM journals by paying a total of $198 a year for membership and access to the ACM Digital Library. ...or, you can go to your local university library in person and get access for free.

As of 2016, Scihub - removing barriers in the way of science. You can request papers at reddit.com/r/Scholar  2011 answer: Do some low-intensity research through your local university's astronomy or atmospheric science department (they often tend to be really liberal in giving UNIX accounts to users - including high school students [1]). They'll usually give you an account to store stuff in. Then set up SSH tunneling through the departmental account that you have, and then you can remotely read the journals that the university has access to. [1] At least at my university. I actually also got access to an Applied Math UNIX account too. I'm pretty sure this is similar across other universities as well - see Are scientists more willing to share data in some fields than in other fields?. If your university doesn't have astronomy/atmospheric science departments, then try a Physics, Applied Math, or Biostatistics department.

Welcome to the real world. We refer to these entities as Paywalls.  When you submit a paper, and it is accepted, the conference/journal (in most of the cases) shares the rights with the publishers like IEEE, ACM etc. There are such research publishers in almost every field of study. There's a lot of debate about this. There are few open access journals which let you get papers for free - and in turn they charge authors more than other publishers. There are very few good quality Open Access journals. Last week, Elsevier, a top research publisher announcd that it would be donating 45 free ScienceDirect accounts to “top Wikipedia editors,” granting them access to thousands of paywalled scientific journals. However this outraged the scientific community as this can in-turn become an event that would strengthen the paywalls. If you're affiliated to a university or a research organization, they would have an institute account with most of top scientific publishers. Check your library and request them for access.  Another option might be contacting authors directly - doesn't always work. If they are super busy researchers, they might not even read your email. An alternative is to look into homepage of the authors - where they usually share the PDF versions for free download. Or Google the title up along with filetype tag e.g. filetype:pdf Distributed Representations of Words and Phrases and their Compositionality Last, if you are still unable to find, request a peer who has access through the paywalls to help you find the required papers.

Unpaywall. They harvest Open Access content from over 50,000 publishers and repositories, and make it easy to find, track, and use. They're integrated into thousands of library systems, search platforms, and other information products worldwide. In fact, if you're involved in scholarly communication, there's a good chance you've already used Unpaywall data. Unpaywall is run by Impactstory, a nonprofit dedicated to making scholarship more accessible to everyone. Open is our passion. So it's only natural our source code is open, too. The Unpaywall database has a very simple structure: we have one record for every article with a Crossref DOI (that's about 95 million records all told). We harvest from lots of sources to find Open Access content, and then we match it to these DOIs using content fingerprints. So, for any given DOI, we know about any OA versions that exist anywhere (at least that's the idea). Institutional Repository managers can use Unpaywall data to find OA resources that faculty have posted online, without depositing in their IR. These can be automatically ingested, significantly increasing IR coverage without needing to convince faculty to deposit. Repositories of all sizes have used Unpaywall data in this way. Of course, this is just a very quick overview...if you have any questions, or want to use Unpaywall in a way that's not described in their website, please drop us a line and they'll be happy to help!

Free options: If you're only interested in a small number of papers then contacting the author(s) to request a copy for personal use can be effective. If you're looking for more general access then you can search the Directory of Open Access Journals. PubMed and other databases also allow you to limit your search to free papers. If you are eligible to join Researchgate , Academia.edu or Figshare you may be able to get hold of papers posted there by the authors. Searching university repositories using the Institutional Repository Search, or even just a Google search for the title of the paper can also yield results. Reduced cost options:Some professional organizations offer journal access as part of their membership package. In that case you would need to be eligible for membership, and pay the necessary fees, but it usually works out much cheaper than paying for papers individually or buying a subscription. DeepDyve has already been covered here. I've used it a few times when I was between institutional subscriptions, but often found they did not have the paper I needed. Still worth a look as they continue to add publishers.

Definitely check Sci-Hub Projects, they are removing barriers in the way of science EDIT: The link might be down, access the site on the new URL http://sci-hub.cc/ This is what they say about themselves: "We fight inequality in knowledge access across the world. The scientific knowledge should be available for every person regardless of their income, social status, geographical location and etc. Our mission is to remove any barrier which impeding the widest possible distribution of knowledge in human society!" This is what Wikipedia says about it: "Sci-Hub is an online repository of over 48,000,000 scientific academic papers and articles,available through its website. New papers are uploaded daily after accessing them through .edu proxies. Founded by Alexandra Elbakyan, a software developer and neurotechnology researcher from Kazakhstan, in 2011, it began as a reaction to the high cost of research papers behind paywalls..." Link full wiki: Sci-Hub " Imagine the world with free access to knowledge for everyone ‐ a world without any paywalls."

An increasing number of journals now publish open access, which means that anyone can read them for free. In some fields, it is common to publish pre-prints of articles before they are submitted to journals. Pre-print servers such as arXiv provide access to these.Many authors publish pre-print versions of their papers, or sometimes even the final versions, on their university web servers or sites like ResearchGate. You can find all of the above through searches on Google Scholar, which will often include direct PDF links in the results.Even closed journals publish titles and abstracts of all their articles. If you find something you want to read, you can email the authors and they will almost certainly send you a copy of the paper.You could try the twitter hashtag #icanhazpdf. Post with details of the paper you want, and someone who doesn't care about the copyright may well send you a copy.You can go to your local university library and read the paper copies of journals they have on their shelves. You may be able to access electronic journals for free from their public terminals, or pay an annual fee to join as an affiliate member.

I don’t know someone has listed this website or not as there are 100+ answer to this question so I can’t go through each answer- I will tell you this simple method of accessing almost any research paper for free by taking an example- Step 1: Search for the topic you want to read research paper on-  Step 2: Open any link-  (As you can see you can not get this paper for free if you don’t have a membership). Step 4: Scroll down and try to find the DOI of paper(You can get access by name also but using DOI is the best option), Here DOI link is given below article information-  Step 5: Right-click on the link and copy the link address of DOI-  Step 6: Now go to another tab of your browser and type “SCIHUB”-  Step 7: Click on the first link and this will open-  Step 8: Paste the link address here and click on open and wait till magic happens-  Hope you find this useful. Image source:Google. Udbhav!

Yes. This is a w0nderful site, which allows you to get most stuff (though not all): http://sci-hub.io ……………… UPDATE, august 2016: sci-hub . io does not work, but sci-hub . cc DOES work. The academic publisher$ HATE sci-hub, and they are doing their best to shut it down. But as soon as they shut down one link, another pops up. Use the “cc” extension for now. ……………….. Also, you can try embedding "sci-hub . io" in the url of your target. Example: Say that this is your target: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih . gov/pubmed/26427314 Try this, inserting "sci-hub . io" after the domain: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih . gov.sci-hub . io/pubmed/26427314 ... usually it works! In the example, you have to click on "full text" link to get the pdf file. Also, you have to omit the blankspaces, which I inserted to get around quora's annoying habit of not displaying literal urls.

Google Scholar, which indexes closed- and open access articles, is the obvious answer. Because bundles multiple copies of the same article, it is often possible to find pre-print and author-hosted copies of paywalled articles.  The Directory of Open Access Journals is a global search index of OA journals, and hosts an article-level search. SCI-HUB.CC is the living mirror of sci-hub.io, a Russian piracy site for academic articles. (Elsevier got the dot-IO domain shut down[1])  AAAAARG.FAIL is the latest domain of one of the first academic piracy communities. As an ask-and-provide user-submission community, it's definitely biased towards the interests of the early-adopters of academic piracy (especially critical theory). This community stands alone as offering full copies of scanned books, and sometimes the only ebook versions ever produced of key texts (yes, people actually stand over a scanner to fulfill requests). I believe that it may be invite only now so it's worth searching the index to see if it has anything relevant before asking around for an invite. (If you're a scholar in a developing country, email me.) Footnotes[1] Elsevier Complaint Shuts Down Sci-Hub Domain Name - TorrentFreak

The library, either public or the one in the nearest academic or other research institution is probably the best bet.  In addition, you can try various working paper repositories, such as arXiv and SSRN. Even further, you might also try authors' personal/professional websites and social networks such as ResearchGate or Academia.edu - Share research. Many publishers permit republishing of pre-prints, which have the same exact content than the published paper, on personal websites or institutional repositories either straight away or after an embargo.  Google Scholar search is actually quite clever crawling through the depths of the web and linking to any available copies. I suppose a disclaimer is in order though. To be on the safe side, please check your local copyright legislation re: your sources before accumulating a major cache of research papers.

HI There ! Research papers and publications are the stepping stones of doing research and molding it into publications. The wonderful people and our wonderful emphatic fraternity of researchers know how crucial it is to have access to unabated flow of research articles at our behest. There are many Facebook fora where a anyone, not having subscriptions of journals, can put links of the desired papers and people having access share the publications with a lead time of average thirty minutes. Kudos to the good Samaritans. (Inserting links below) The second and more potent way is using sci-hub portal which is a pirated site having a success rate of 99.9%. Just paste the url of the publication on the sci-hub portal. To make it more handy, add sci-hub google chrome extension which makes the DOIs clicktable Log into Facebook | Facebook Log into Facebook | Facebook Scientific Research Papers Request removing barriers in the way of science

Well, I personally believe that every research work should be available with open access to anyone. Research is a collaborative work and I don't understand the logic behind the subscriptions and other fees, as most of research scholars are unemployed with basic or no sapient money. If you have a great publication with restricted access, I'd say that it is a complete waste as a very meager percentage of research community can actually read or work upon your idea. Having said that, visit Sci-Hub to download research papers and articles for free. I'd say that it is a researchers heaven in the form of  an online repository of over 48,000,000 scientific academic papers and articles, available through its website. New papers are uploaded daily. :)

arxiv.org publishes many papers, for free, though since they aren't peer reviewed their status as "scientific" can be dubious.   plos.org also publishes free papers, and they are peer reviewed. They and others are aggregated at the Directory of Open Access Journals, http://www.doaj.org/. In general, Google Scholar (scholar.google.com) is an excellent search tool for free and non-free papers.  Often, the abstracts are available for free even if the paper is not, and for people searching just "scientific" papers rather than a specific field the abstract may be all you need.

Yes. First off, publications in many journals (PLOS and BMC among others) are publicly available right away. For many other journals, the electronic copy becomes available after a certain period of time (say a year) so unless you need that paper that just came out last month, you will probably be able to get it. Some journals never make their stuff available unless you have a subscription (personally, I try to stay away from publishing in these journals if I can). And this is the big one. If you do a pubmed or google scholar search and see a paper that looks interesting to you, just contact one of the authors and ask for a copy of the paper. They will always oblige. Even if it's not quite the publication version of the paper (it could be a galley proof or an MS Word version), they will hook you up with a version that is pretty close to the final version.

Sci-hub.  I've tried it, it works. But it appears to be down at the moment (05-11-2016). From Wikipedia: "Sci-Hub is an online repository of over 51,000,000 scientific academic papers and articles,available through its website. New papers are uploaded daily after accessing them through .edu proxies. Founded by Alexandra Elbakyan from Kazakhstan in 2011, it began as a reaction to the high cost of research papers behind paywalls, typically US$30 each when bought on a per-paper basis. Academic publisher Elsevier has in 2015 filed a legal complaint in New York City alleging copyright infringement by Sci-Hub." You can read more here: Is Sci-Hub offline?

With a public library card you can access, at the very least, the online database Academic Search Premier from your library district's website. (See, for example: http://douglascountylibraries.org/Research/A-Z ) If your library district has more money, you could probably access even meatier sources, but according to the publisher (EBSCO) of Academic Search Premier, which is basic to most public libraries:  Academic Search Premier contains indexing and abstracts for more than 8,500 journals, with full text for more than 4,600 of those titles. PDF backfiles to 1975 or further are available for well over one hundred journals, and searchable cited references are provided for more than 1,000 titles.Academic Search Premier contains unmatched full-text coverage in biology, chemistry, engineering, physics ...

I assume the question is meant to ask “Is there a website to read the research papers for free”? . -There is no single website where one can access research papers for no cost. Usually, the publishers like IEEE, Nature, Science, Springer, Elsevier, and many others don't make their articles available for free to the public. This has been a subject of debate for quite a few years and has resulted in the emergence of “Open access journals”. These journals make their articles accessible to all, only caveat is that the publisher fee needs to be borne by the authors. Nevertheless, this concept is increasingly getting popular and there are a lot of OA journals these days. One can find the list of OA journals here: (go through the relevant research topic) List of open access journals - Wikipedia If you want non-OA journals for free, then either Share and discover research or Academia.edu - Share research could help if the authors have uploaded their articles to these websites.

Bad luck. Major online distributors of research publications like sciencedirect and Scopus do not give free access to publications. You need to subscribe to them with a hefty annual fee. Without subscriptions, you will have to pay for each paper that you want to study and again, the prices are pretty steep. The abstracts of all the papers, however, are available free of cost. Of course, you can try Google Scholar and normal Google search. If you have a specific topic in your mind, once in a while you will get the desired publication. But chances of finding a quality publication from a reputed journal for free is almost nil. If you are associated with a university or research institute, find out if the institute has access to the aforementioned online sources, generally the good ones do.  If you are doing this thing independently, only legal option available is, paying for whatever you want.

Some, but not all, scholarly papers are behind paywalls. So, the question becomes, “How do you get behind the paywalls without emptying your wallet?” The easiest way is through a university library if you have privileges there. There you get access to everything they have. Second, try searching your keywords of interest on Scholar.Google.com. Some of the articles will come up behind paywalls and others will be free. Finally, look for other resources. Take a look at dspace.mit.edu. There, you can access many theses and dissertations. Again, use your keywords to narrow your search. Good luck in your search.

Well easiest or straightforward option would be to google some thing like this "E-cigarettes cause indoor air pollution and inflammation pdf" This should try and help you get the relevant materials to quite an extent. There are a few Google tips on how you can better your search also. An alternative is to go to the following link and search.Google Scholar The above should be quite helpful and at times it links to a pdf if available. Other alternatives would include, considering you are not at a University, trying to find someone, a friend perhaps at a university and asking them for help. University libraries usually have subscriptions to conference and journal proceedings where you can find the papers for free.

A few things to add: Google Scholar will give you a link to the paper on the right side of the screen if one is readily availableIf you have a specific paper you want to access and can’t find it online, email the corresponding author (start with the first listed author if no corresponding author is specified); the authors usually can and are eager to share their researchIf you Google “scihub”, you may get a link to the current location of sci-hub, a Russian effort to share all published research. It’s not… um… legal, which is why the link switches; the publishing companies get court orders to shut the site down, and then it moves elsewhere. You’ll need the DOI (a reference identifier) for the paper.

The other answers are great, here are a few other tricks. 1. If your local library doesn't have the resources you need then get an out-of-area library card for a great library.  For $25 per year I have access to many research databases including ebscohost from a library in Georgia USA. 2. Many journals offer free access for public libraries.  If you take a journal's information to a reference librarian you may be able to convince them to sign up.  My local library accepted my request for Physical Review Letters and will be adding it to their online resources this quarter. 3. You can try writing the corresponding author a request for the paper.  My success rate is ~70% with this.  Keep the emails short and courteous. 4. You can search for the author's homepage or CV.  Many will have links to published papers. Best of luck.

For users who happen to be unaffiliated with a university, unfortunately your choices are limited.  For recent grads or people that work in companies with limited budgets, we started DeepDyve (http://www.deepdyve.com) where we let users and enterprises "rent" journal articles via our cloud-based service.  Users can read the full-text for as little as $0.99 per article, or join a monthly plan starting at $5.  We've partnered with most of the major publishers and would love to get your feedback on how we can improve our service.

Some of the following websites or portals may help:  Google Scholar: One can search for articles in their field of interest and can find links to access full text articles freely.researchgate.net : Researchers have their profiles here and they have their articles uploaded on this portal. So one can download them easily or in case the article doesn't have full text, one can send request to authors through this website.sci-hub.io : Although it's not right ethically to get articles on this portal but you can just put the DOI of any article here and voila you'll get the pdf of that article.

In CS—or at least the parts of CS I care about—I've always just found papers on their author's websites. Usually through Google. CiteSeerX is another good source. I always hit it from Google search though—I've never bothered using its search directly. It also has BibTeX entries for papers, which is very useful when you need to cite something. You could also use scholar.google.com which does a good job of searching for papers. At least for CS queries, you often get a list of PDF links on the side:  Results for functional reactive programming

As my students have faced this problem, I’ve found a number of resources. Some work better than others. Others are updated versions of sites given by other answers. I hope this helps: http://www.jurn.org http://www.freefullpdf.com https://doaj.org/ https://knowtro.com/ https://www.sciencealert.com/ https://scihub.org/ https://www.plos.org/

There is a growing trend in open access publishing, so you can now read papers for free from many popular peer-reviewed journals. If the paper you are interested is in a journal that charges readers, I know of two other options. (1) In many fields (Physics, Mathematics, Computer Science, Quantitative Biology, Quantitative Finance, and Statistics) it is common for authors to reprint their papers at arxiv.org. (2) You can write to the author and request a copy of their paper. Most paid journals do not prohibit their authors from sharing their paper with individuals, and I expect that many authors would be happy to help someone without a subscription to read their paper.

Academic institutions and companies heavily involved in research typically purchase subscriptions to online repositories such as the ACM Digital Library, allowing their employees to access many articles under this subscription.  Otherwise, you may have luck finding articles on the websites of the authors (the first author is your best bet, assuming a field where ordering of authors matters). For instance, I provide links to all of my papers on my personal website.  Google Scholar (http://scholar.google.com/) can assist in finding papers as well.

You can access a lot of SAE material through college libraries, industry groups, etc. You probably won't be able to download them, but you'll be able to access them. At a college library, for example, you would likely be able to scan or copy the pages you need. Some businesses will grant you access, i.e. because you're a student and they're associated with the school in some form, but you wouldn't be allowed to copy anything significant. Privately, not happening for legit stuff. If you are an engineer, I would highly encourage you to look at the ethics of downloading what amounts to pirated documents. It may seem harmless, but you wouldn't likely be happy if people were stealing information that you had invested time and money in developing.

Customarily, access to medical science journals are divided into areas: those that are "free access" and those that aren't.   If  you're graduate student often you don't need additional privilege.  In some cases, you can go to your local library and the library has a license to access to databases of journals that don't require additional cost than the cost of a library card. I would recommend that you try some of the local libraries for "free access" or for low cost access to paid s ubscrptions. Richard Hom  Go Fund Me My Diabetes Resarch

There are far too many repositories and open access journals to list them here. If a specific field of research was mentioned it might be possible to list a few main ones. One good way to find free copies of specific papers is to search in Google Scholar. You can also find or request free copies in ResearchGate and/or Academia.edu - Share research if you are signed up. You may also find the http://Jstor.org “Free to Read” service useful. If you sign up they let you read a small number of papers from a large number of major journals for free.

Note some of these are completely free while some contains free journals and paid journals:-InTech - Open Science Open MindsThe Journal of Biological ChemistryScience and Education PublishingAgricultural Institute of CanadaAMINO ACID COMPOSITION AND NITROGEN-TO-PROTEIN FACTORS FOR GRAIN LEGUMESScienceOpenAn Open Access Journalhttp://www.fasebj.org/  Occasionally, if you do a google search on a particular topic, you will can get free journals from these sites (even if not all of the journals from their site is free)Nature Publishing Group : science journals, jobs, and information (Actually they redirect you to the site where the journal is located) ACS Publications Home PageThe Journal of Biological ChemistryPage on nih.govDepartment of ChemistryNext-generation and Wireless Communications LaboratoryPage on berkeley.eduWelcome::INTERNATIONAL JOURNAL OF EMERGING TECHNOLOGY AND ADVANCED ENGINEERING (IJETAE)Molecular Biology and EvolutionProceedings of the Royal Society of London B: Biological Sciencesand lots more

Most of the top rated journals today have a paid subscription model or individual article purchase. But as you might know this costs a lot. The best way to get these article for free is to approach any social network where you can get in touch with the authors directly. ResearchGate is one such forum. You can view the publications by author and also request for a full text. If the concerned author is not available on any such forums, the best way is to send an email requesting for a full text of the required paper. In most of the cases the authors will be more than happy to help you out.All the best.

We can access 83 Million research paper free of cost through Sci-hub. Step 1: Search your research paper topic on Google Scholar then visit the research paper where it published Step 2: Copy the url or Doi number of the research paper Step 3: Then visit Sci-hub and paste your Doi or url that you copied before Step 5: Then click on open and you get the research paper as a pdf file You can Watch this video for better understanding  Youtube Channel Name: youtube.com/c/ClearConceptFamily

1) Search for the paper adding pdf at the end of it. Chances are that it is available online by other providers freely. 2) Join social groups like these where you can request a research paper:FacebookThe Users typically respond to you by sending the paper link or inboxing you with the paper. 3) If its expensive, its good. May be a lot of other people are searching for the paper too. Find the author of the paper and try to mail them requesting access to the paper in sites like Google scholar, ResearchGate, Academia, etc. You'll have helped a lot others too. I'm sure the authors would respond.    Hope it helps

Usually, authors host their papers on personal websites or their research group/lab websites. You can access the papers from such websites. Or what you can do is check on free research websites such as http://Academia.edu or http://Researchgate.net , they allow you to access papers for free if you are a member which is free.  Worst case, if you know any friends in other colleges which have subscribed to IEEE Xplore subscription then you can ask them to download any particular topic's papers and send to you. Hope that helps :)

What you can do and what may seem extreme to you right now, is mail the authors and ask them for a copy of the paper. They reply more often than you think. Tell them about your project or interest and that you can't access the paper. They also feel pleased  if you ask them doubts or for some clarification.  I've done this a few times. It works. Other times ask your professors or friends who have subscription. Contacts work better than we assume.

Hai, You can use removing barriers in the way of science . Here you can have access to research papers for free. Well I’ll add another link which might be helpful to you with your research work http://en.pudn.com/ Here you should sign up first and then you can have access to research papers or codes. they avail you two options for this. You can be a VIP member by paying some bucks and then you can have access to the content in the site orYou can have free access by uploading some source code or some documents. You’ll get points the more you upload the docs or codes.If you try it with 2nd option you can download 20 papers per day. Hope this helps! P.S: This is not ethical but research work needs to study more and paying for all these may be difficult, hence making use of these sites for references may not be that bad!

Academic institutions and companies heavily involved in research typically purchase subscriptions to online repositories such as the https://www.prescottpapers.com/, allowing their employees to access many articles under this subscription. Otherwise, you may have luck finding articles on the websites of the authors (the first author is your best bet, assuming a field where ordering of authors matters). For instance, I provide links to all of my papers on my personal website.

Yes, there is a search engine for open-access material: jurn.org  Also, if you register as an "independent scholar" at Academia.edu, you can start following people and get email updates when they put up new articles. A lot of older material is on JSTOR . You can open a free account there which lets you read three articles onscreen every two weeks (but not download anything). Finally, it is generally accepted that a professor may share copies of non-open material with colleagues for the purpose of cultivating further research. You can join this exclusive club by writing a suitably fawning e-mail. ;-)

For physics/math: ArXiv arXiv.org e-Print archive If there is a particular paper you are looking for, and you/your school does not have a subscription, try googling for the website of the group or individual who authored the paper.  They will often have a list of publications available for free on their site.

There is pirate website for research papers founded by a Russian woman named Alexandra Elbakyan[1] . The purpose of this platform is to make knowledge available for free. In world where single research paper costs more than $30, how are we suppose to do study. The website is: http://sci-hub.tw Sometimes the website is taken down, so they use different domain name. You can use google and simply search sci-hub[2] for alternative site. If it is in your capacity do make donations to them. Footnotes[1] Alexandra Elbakyan - Wikipedia[2] Sci-Hub - Wikipedia

If you live near a university or community college, you could look into if they allow members of the public into the library. It's also possible your local public library will have access to a journal database. Also, if you have a friend who goes to a university, you might politely ask them for their login information so you can access articles through their online student account. Hehe, am I allowed to say things here if they're not exactly legal?

Where can I read peer-reviewed science articles for free? There are many journals that are open access. You might consult http://www.doaj.org/. A couple of popular ones include PeerJ, and the entire family of http://www.plos.org/ journals, including http://www.plosone.org/ (which is, I think, the biggest journal in the world now).  Why aren't all peer-reviewed papers in the open domain?  Many reasons, not least of which is the scientific publishing system was created when there was no Internet. (I remember those times, but many don't now.) You don't toss away a working distribution system overnight.  Where is a good place to read peer-reviewed articles, papers, journals, etc for free?  For biomedical research, http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/. http://scholar.google.com/ also links to PDFs and full text when it can find them.  Is Write better papers, faster! worth subscription? No idea.

Most State Universities subscribe to a lot of online journals, and will let the general public use their computers to access these journals for an hour if you are doing serious research. There are many distributors of these online journals: each of them distribute journals in only select topics. Check your local University Library to see if you could be permitted to use this access. You may be asked to describe the type of work, and the type of journals, you wish to study.

I failed to understand to pay for research papers. It doesn't make sense particularly incase of students who are not on any payrolls. Selling knowledge is absurd.Instead of using proxy servers/website to download papers it is better to request authors for the copy and most of the time authors respond positively.ResearchGate has a good data base now, so you should always try RG if you are unable to download from Google scholar etc“ Share knowledge,make world a common Home”

How to access many paywalled scholarly, journal, or research paper? 1. Open Access Button 2. PubMed 3. Google Scholar 4. Try a regular web search for papers on their personal or lab website. 5. Sci-Hub 6. Use your school  or institution' online or physical library 7. Ask your local research library if you can buy a pass. How to Access Paywalled Scientific Journal Articles

Q: “How can I access research papers for free?” You can access to research papers legally through: searching in Google Scholar and other search engines in the internet;visiting websites of the authors and their departments and institutions;directly contact the authors and request for a copy for using in research and study, not for distribution, sharing and selling;visiting the journals’ websites to see if the paper is open access.

Only a complete arsehole pays to read any paper. I never do. Learn how to download things. Get a library card or find a mate who has one. If you look up papers on Google Scholar you find that you can download most papers for free. A lot of academics put their papers up on Research Gate where you can download them. Also most pay-to-read papers are not worth the paper you print them on anyway. Old fashioned but send an email to the author and ask them for a copy.

The local University library. Yes, the Internet is convenient, but there was science before it and the library was the place to be. Most libraries have inter-library loans with other libraries, so you should be able to have access to anything you want.

Simple, use Sci-Hub! They just did a domain switch to removing barriers in the way of science To read more about the latest Sci-Hub saga, see Science Magazine’s Defense of Expensive Journals Is Hilariously Flawed

Are you affiliated with a college/university library (preferably one with a significant engineering program)?  They might have SAE journals available through their various online databases, which you could be able to use through their website (you'd need to log in). Even if you're not affiliated with them, you should check to see if you have access if you visit the library in person. Otherwise, you'd need to have a paid subscription to a source like the SAE Digital Library--there is no free access to that. If you already have citations from those journals and just need to track down the full-text articles, you can simply ask your local library if they can request a copy of those articles from another library via interlibrary loan. They might have a slight charge for that, but often don't.

> Why aren't all peer-reviewed papers in the open domain? Because there are established companies that want to make money >  Where is a good place to read peer-reviewed articles, papers, journals, etc for free?  arXiv.org e-Print archive"Free" for you if you're a student: Probably from your universities network, e.g. http://www.sciencedirect.com or http://ieeexplore.ieee.org > Finally, is http://Questia.com worth  subscription? I have never heard of that website

Go on Google Scholar, search the keywords. As the search results are listed, the links having a pdf copies will have have a hyperlink just adjacent to the name.All the papers uploaded on Academia.edu ,researchgate.com and on university websites, having valid google scholar profiles are listed in Google Scholar. If you don't find the names you are searching for, go and search for them individually on these websites.

Make an account on Research Gate : https://www.researchgate.net/home Follow the researchers that are inherent with your research field and ask them a private copy of their papers. You can also write them an email. Another alternative seems to be Science Huβ LLC, Leading the Information Highway  It is not legal in all states but it remains an alternative.

You can ask the authors for a soft copy. Whether they oblige is another question. There may be some copyright issues. Usually, all decent size universities and libraries have institutional subscriptions to most important archives, e.g. IEEE Xplore. So if you have any affiliation with an institute it should not be a problem. If not, get a library membership. Or befriend someone who is actually affiliated with a university. Arxive has free copies of a lot of articles in my field.

SAE articles aren't available to the general public unless you have a paid subscription. It's done like that to protect the work and integrity of the engineering process and copyright. Some Colleges and University's Faculty of Automotive Engineering have acccess to the standards set forth by SAE but is strictly intended for teaching purposes only. The membership cost is expensive since you need to pay by article request. There are some journals that have been released due to revisions, adaptations of different standards and procedures, and DOT requirements.

http://www.mendeley.com/ has a nice collection of papers (deposited by the authors), you can find quite a lot of PDFs. As mentionned, http://scholar.google.com does a good job of finding PDFs. And of course, searching for the web page of one of the authors is most of the time the fastest way to find a paper!

The library genesis website is an excellent resource for accessing research papers for free. I find it very useful if I am not using my institute internet. The legality of such sites is questionable, though. EDIT: Here is an interesting article discussing the Lib-Gen and Sci-Hub projects.

There are many open-access journals (those articles are freely available), and you can also find loads of preprints on the arXiv preprint server. Additionally, many people post their papers on their websites.

Developing countries get free access to thousands of journals (including BMJ, JAMA and NEJM) through the HINARI initiative (http://www.who.int/hinari), so if you're in a qualifying country you should be able to get access to what you're looking for. If not, you can freely access a lot of open access material anyway, such as original articles in the BMJ, wherever in the world you are. Happy reading!

Search your paper in Google, Google Scholar. It is most likely that the paper (or the pre-print version) is available to download.  If still it is not available, mail to the corresponding author, he/she will be glad to send you the paper. You can forward the article link to friends who have access to the article.

On http://researchgate.net, people make their own articles available for the public. You don't need to sign up to access a lot of articles. But you do need to sign up to request articles from authors. That's actually how people used to get articles. By requesting the author to send them a copy by mail.

For publication of research paper the best easy and free method for students and any one , so far as i think , state ( as Bihar etc.) council of science Technology and indian science congress. one can search about these two on GOOGLE. For member in ISC about Rs 250 / per yr or live Rs 2500 / needed. and one can submit own paper. in Scst as Bihar (bsct ) free. for other state one can consult GOOGLE or own science and technology ministry etc. except these two all are needing much money and many a ado and formality. submission method in them is simple by email or by regd. post. Be careful of publishing mafias always. they are wandering on internet with their shops etc. thanks.

Use http://gen.lib.rus.ec/scimag/. Note that this probably is not the legal way to obtain access to papers. In case you do not prefer this method, follow other ways as explained in the rest of the answers.

http://www.researchgate.net is the website. You can get the papers if author has uploaded it. One can always request author to upload full paper. Discussions on this forum are also nice. It's best way to ask doubts directly to authors and experts in the field.

Free sites are always lack of data.There is a way to download academic papers for free.Just go to a library and use the computer there. (Libraries of universities are better sometimes) Because a library always buys the access of many acdemic sites. (At least in China...... I don't know if it works in other countries.)Hope helpful. ^_^

If you attend a research university, you may be able to get research papers from a lot of private journals for free. For example, if I find a paper that looks interesting, I just go to my school's library website, log in, and access the journal through there.

You can go for open access journals, who are free to access and does not charge any amount for publishing and downloading papers For example- ELK Asia Pacific Journals -as they are open access -Have indexing database in - Journals directory, google scholar, sherpa Romeo, Indian science etc -Have DOI to every paper also ISSN and ISBN number to every paper -Provide journals in 13 domains which covers almost all the topics available
Try the following online resources http://scholar.google.comResearchGate | Share and discover researchAcademia.edu - Share research

It is best advised to contact the researcher or publisher of the exact paper for the copy rather than the governing body since they charge you for the access, while researchers tend to provide exemplary drafts of their work quite often.
Just copy paste either URL or doi no of the article you need access in removing barriers in the way of science This works almost well for all science based journals. I have not tried other fields.

In addition to all the mentioned sources to get manuscripts; I would like to add Academia.edu - Share research  by referring to the word of Richard Price the founder of Academia.edu. “The goal of Academia.edu - Share research is to get every science PDF ever written on the internet, accessible for free. We want to make science faster and more open”

Use google scholar and there is an impressive amount of downloadable free pdf papers there. Or get a list of the top open access journals (eg Cogent Social Sciences). You might also find a free trial now and then. The other option is to go to authors’ web pages as you might find some downloadable resources that way.

If you're affiliated with a hospital or university you might be able to request certain articles from the librarian staff that are behind pay walls (the articles, not the librarians). Certain. Articles. Handing them a vague topic for them to research will not endear you, or get you any results.

If we are talking about health research paper, then there are few to be named like 1) Home - PubMed - NCBI (Some free, some paid) 2) Biomedical Research - Embase (mostly paid) 3) Cochrane Library ( Free) 4)Ovid: Welcome to Ovid (Paid) One thing you can do is search the article in the database to make search systematic, and go to google scholar, research gate and others to search for free article. The best way to access any journal which doesn't have open access too. removing barriers in the way of science (http://sci-hub.bz/) Just open the above link, copy the link from any journal(where we read abstract and demand us to purchase to read the whole paper), paste and hit the enter key. The journal will be downloaded in a pdf. I have downloaded loads of journals from Springer, Elsevier and other services too.

I've mainly been using google scholar but I just discovered BioMedSearch which claims:  "BioMedSearch is a biomedical search engine that contains NIH/PubMed documents, a large collection of theses, dissertations, and other proprietary publications not found anywhere else for free, making it one of the most comprehensive and powerful free biomedical searches." http://www.biomedsearch.com/
Social science research network (SSRN) is the best source for accessing research papers on any topic for free. You can also find some on scribd and academia as well but SSRN is best.
For dairy topics, you can acess Journal of Dairy Science ( http://journalofdairyscience.org/) . You can review a lot of articles for free.
go to scholar in google and then find whatever topic paper u want to find

Although there is no such sites available from where you can freely download all kinds of papers but there are some groups on Facebook from where you can request for the same.Some of the Facebook groups are:1. Research paper request2. Paper request

Sci hub offers a huge collection of research papers for academics to use. Copy the DOI of the paper from the journal they are published in and use sci hub to search your paper. You can find papers in a variety of languages. In addition to this most articles are available on google scholar. I would recommend you add .pdf to the search function so you can find the paper easily.
You can visit some scholars' website, most of them provide their papers on their site for free. You can also send email to some scholars to ask papers, they are often pleased to share.

There is no free lunch. If you are looking for paid lunch then you can try acm or ieee. Both are good but ieee is more expensive and has more papers in their library. I am a current subscriber of acm and i'm quite satisfied with the quantity of papers they have. PS: Google has a "free" library called "Google Scholar" but I could never find anything worthwhile on that.

Try Google Scholar - there are links to various version of articles from those found on publisher websites, PubMed, PubMedCentral, etc., to those a researcher has posted to their university's webpage or repository.
The best option, and the one that I use now, is: http://sci-hub.cc/ I just sincerely hope that mentioning the website here doesn’t cause it to be taken down. *fingers crossed*

First of all writing a research paper review is not at all a simple task. And also it is an essential part of the writing process in higher education. In this situation the students seeking help from online writing services. There are many writing services available in the internet. But it is really luck to find out one high quality service provider. And also the main aim of each service is to satisfy their customers. So you better to approach a good writing service and refer the samples from it. I hope then you will get the ideas about the evaluation criteria of research paper reviews.

The best place where research papers are freely available is Google Scholar. google.scholar.google.co.in Here you can type related keywords or even the name of paper. The search results will have a pdf link to download the papers.
Hi, You can check at the publisher’s site if the paper is free, and then download it. Another way is to copy/paste the title into Google Scholar, and sometimes it is found there in full text.
